report_title: Orange & Citrus Groves in the US
executive_summary: Orange and citrus farmers grow and sell oranges, grapefruit, lemons and tangerines, which are among the most popular foods in the United States. Citrus fruit consumption tends to rise with the growing population, but severe disruptions in recent years have not borne this out...

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Huanglongbing (HLB), also called citrus greening, destroys citrus crops by discoloring their skin and turning them green.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Disease Caused Citrus Production to Drop Noticeably in Florida During the 2018 - 2019 Season, Resulting in a Major Drop in Revenue for Orange and Citrus Farmers.
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Citrus greening has recently been spreading to California and has the potential to disrupt the industry there as well. There's been no proven cure for HLB in citrus fruits, so the disease remains very threatening.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Pandemic Produced Mixed Results for the Industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: COVID-19 led to a major decline in spending on citrus fruits in some key areas, such as lemon growers that served bars and farmers that primarily exported their products. Demand for citrus fruits held up in some other sectors, as they were still a necessary component in the diets of many Americans...
Since citrus fruits are often consumed as snacks, there's significant competition from other foods that can be eaten throughout the day, such as chips, candy and non-citrus fruits.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: EXPORT MARKETS STRUGGLE AMID ECONOMIC DISRUPTIONS
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Exports of citrus fruit to other countries have been lagging during the current period, as an appreciating dollar has made domestically made goods more expensive. Farmers must also compete with citrus producers from other countries, such as Chile and Mexico, which have significantly lower labor costs...

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: INFLATION HAS MADE INPUT COSTS UNBEARABLE FOR SMALL OPERATORS
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Supply chain disruptions, loose monetary policy and excessive government spending have caused inflation to spike recently. Rising prices have made the costs of inputs for citrus farmers, such as fertilizers, fuel and machinery, very expensive...

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: THE FALLING DOLLAR WILL BE A BOON FOR CITRUS FARMERS SELLING ABROAD
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Demand for US currency will decline significantly during the outlook period, resulting in a major depreciation of the dollar. When the dollar is lower in value, domestically produced goods are less costly to foreigners so exports rise. Since citrus farmers export much of their produce, this will result in surging revenue...

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: CONTINUED INVESTMENT IN SUBSIDIES TO FIGHT CITRUS DISEASES WILL PROVIDE MAJOR RELIEF
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Since 2014, congress has appropriated tens of billions of dollars in funding to the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) to invest in research to fight diseases, such as Huanglongbing (HLB) and Asian citrus psyllid (ACP)...

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: GENETIC MODIFICATION OF CITRUS FRUITS CAN SAVE THE INDUSTRY FROM UNFORESEEN OUTBREAKS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The company Southern Gardens Citrus has been attempting to genetically modify citrus trees since they identified HLB in 2005. Genetic modification will enable citrus fruit growers to plant and sell their products without the fear of them being wiped out by devastating diseases...

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: EATING ORANGES AND OTHER CITRUS FRUITS WILL BECOME LESS IMPORTANT IN THE AMERICAN DIET
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: More consumers are becoming health conscious, so they've been and will continue to adopt diets low in carbohydrates. Citrus fruits are mostly not part of these diets, as their relatively high sugar content makes them unattractive...

industry_definition: Farmers in this industry primarily grow citrus fruits, including oranges, grapefruits and lemons. Citrus fruits grown in this industry are used in downstream processing industries (e.g., juices, canned fruit) and sold as fresh.
key_trends: Orange and citrus fruit farms are deeply fragmented, as owner-operators comprise the large majority of establishments.
Revenue can fluctuate drastically with weather conditions, preferences and other factors, so many large companies don't enter the industry, keeping consolidation generally low.

Consolidation has risen in recent years, resulting from higher input costs. Fertilizers and machinery have specifically become more costly, as farmers demand more expensive and advanced versions of them.
Despite these trends, orange and citrus fruit farmers remain very fractured.
Orange and citrus farmers have struggled during the current period, as citrus greening, poor exports, penetration from substitutes and high inflation caused revenue to plunge.
The industry held up decently during the pandemic despite these challenges, as the perception that citrus fruits were healthy kept revenue relatively stable.

market_segmentation.segment_description: The market for fresh fruit simply contains oranges, lemons, tangerines and other citrus fruits in their raw form. Fresh fruit has been marketed as being healthy, so consumers concerned about dieting and generally eating well have started to buy them in greater quantities.

The market for processed fruit includes fruit juices and sauces, with orange juice being a major product. Concerns regarding obesity have become very prevalent in recent years, so there's been public and private campaigns to make Americans eat healthier. Since fruit juices contain lots of sugar, spending on them has declined, causing their share of revenue to fall during the current period.

products_and_services.product_description: Navel oranges are dark oranges with thick skin.
Valencia oranges are bright oranges with weaker skin.
Lemons are sour citrus fruits mostly used to flavor food and drinks.

tier_1_suppliers: Farm, Lawn & Garden Equipment Wholesaling in the US
Water Supply & Irrigation Systems in the US
tier_1_buyers: Coal & Natural Gas Power in the US
Commercial Building Construction in the US
Fruit & Vegetable Wholesaling in the US
Canned Fruit & Vegetable Processing in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Increased public concern about nutrition and diet
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Increased public concern about nutrition and diet has had a positive effect on citrus consumption since they have high vitamin content. Citrus fruits also compete with an expanding variety of fruit on the fresh market, which can hurt citrus consumption if prices increase too much.

international_trade_points.trade_title: The United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) Makes Imports From Mexico Attractive
international_trade_points.trade_description: The USMCA reduces many trade barriers between Canada, the United States and Mexico. Since Mexican producers of citrus fruit can grow their products in a more suitable environment with lower labor costs, they have been flooding the US market with their goods since they mostly aren't subject to duties.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Recent Trade Deals With Chile Enable More Commerce With The South American Country
international_trade_points.trade_description: In 2015, the United States and Chile signed an agreement that made all goods between the two countries duty-free. Chile's climate is similar to nations on the Mediterranean Sea, so farmers grow citrus fruits, such as lemons and tangerines. Given the growing popularity of these two fruits and the lack of trade barriers, trade from Chile has surged during the current period.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Import Markets Display Some Shakiness Over Declining Demand For Processed Fruit
international_trade_points.trade_description: Imported citrus fruit is mostly used for processed products, as fruit that displays wear-and-tear after a long journey is not suitable for selling in the United States. As more consumers have strayed away from processed citrus products because of concerns regarding their sugar content, import markets are threatened.

international_trade_points.trade_title: The Pandemic Led To A Plunge In Exports
international_trade_points.trade_description: Concerns regarding the spread of COVID-19 through shipping, the massive drop in demand and disrupted supply chains all contributed to a major decline in exports in 2020.

international_trade_points.trade_title: As The US Dollar Appreciates, Export Markets Face Major Challenges
international_trade_points.trade_description: Demand for US dollars has risen during the current period, causing its value to surge in those years. Domestically produced goods have become more expensive for foreign buyers, so they've bought less of these products, resulting in a major drop in exports for orange and citrus fruit growers in the United States.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Investment In South Korea Builds An Important Revenue Source For Domestic Citrus Fruit Producers
international_trade_points.trade_description: In 2019, Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) in South Korea was $39.1 billion, resulting in more economic development in the East Asian country. Since South Korea is a major importer of US-grown citrus fruits, more investment in the country raises incomes there, resulting in greater spending on citrus products and boosting revenue for the industry.

business_locations.location_description: Florida has a climate that's distinct from the rest of the United States, as it tends to be tropical all year round. These weather conditions enable planters to grow a variety of citrus fruits, especially oranges, where Florida comprises more than half of the nation's orange production.

California's Central Valley is located out west, where much of the climate is characterized as Mediterranean. The weather in this region permits many citrus fruits to be grown, especially grapefruit and lemons. More than half of US citrus fruit production comes out of California.

Farms in Texas and Arizona comprise less than 5.0% of overall citrus fruit production, but both states still have some farms. Farmers in Texas specialize in growing grapefruit, while those in Arizona plant many lemon trees.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) implements regulations called marketing orders for orange and citrus fruit farmers to foster stable markets. These orders maintain a high quality of produce, standardize packages and containers, regulate the flow of products to the market, create reserve programs for excess fruit and authorize research into improving crop yields.

The USDA partners with the Animal and Plant Inspection Service (APHIS) to ensure that imported oranges and citrus fruits are safe for humans and animals to eat. These agencies also promote the export of fruits abroad.

Orange and citrus fruit farmers are regulated at the local level. The size of farms is often restricted by land zoning laws, while citrus fruit growers must also contend with various environmental and safety rules at the state level.

The EPA regulates the release of hazardous wastes into the environment. These can apply to orange and citrus fruit farmers if they have recently used a pesticide that has been recalled. The EPA would require that farmers stop using these pesticides and ensure that the materials wouldn't go to landfills.

Similar to every other industry, orange and citrus grove farmers were required to enforce mask-wearing, social distancing and hand washing to stop the spread of COVID-19. Some establishments forced their employees to get the COVID-19 vaccine when it was released.

basis_points.basis_title: Orange and citrus fruit farms are deeply fragmented
basis_points.basis_description: Owner-operators comprise the large majority of establishments. Revenue can fluctuate.

concentration_points.concentration_description: More than 90.0% of farms are nonemployer entities, indicating that most orange and citrus fruit growers operate as sole proprietorships and partnerships instead of corporations.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Rising Prices Slowly Create More Consolidation
concentration_points.concentration_description: Operating a citrus farm has become more expensive in recent decades, as it requires fertilizer and machinery that have risen in price because of their increasing complexity. Insurance premiums are also higher, which has contributed to the rising costs of operating a farm.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Crop insurance and other expenses are major extra costs for orange and citrus fruit farmers.
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Crop insurance and other expenses are major extra costs for orange and citrus fruit farmers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Miscellaneous costs have soared during the current period
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Miscellaneous costs have soared during the current period, as high-interest rates, inflation and a possible recession have caused many farmers to take out crop insurance.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Long-term concerns about climate change also contribute to the greater prevalence of crop and other forms of insurance.
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Long-term concerns about climate change also contribute to the greater prevalence of crop and other forms of insurance.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: While there are some capital costs, wages represent a major portion of revenue, as many resources are required to pick fruit, drive tractors and manage farms.

volatility_points.volatility_title: WEATHER CONDITIONS CAN RESULT IN MASSIVE REVENUE SWINGS
volatility_points.volatility_description: Warm environments are necessary for the successful growing of citrus fruits, so sudden drops in temperature can ruin a harvest and severely reduce sales for farmers.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Trade Conditions Disrupt Citrus Fruit Sales
volatility_points.volatility_description: Since oranges and other citrus fruits are only grown in limited parts of the United States, such as California, Florida, Texas and Arizona, droughts, storms and spells of cold weather are very threatening for the domestic industry. Many orange and citrus farmers rely on markets from outside the United States to remain profitable. Having a weak dollar is integral to the success of the industry, as consumers abroad will buy domestic produce when their prices are lower. Since exchange rates are constantly fluctuating, they create significant volatility for farmers. Tariffs and trade wars can also cause major disruptions.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: THE GENETIC MODIFICATION OF CITRUS FRUITS HAS BECOME A RECENT IDEA
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Scientists and producers have considered genetically modifying citrus fruits to reduce the spread of diseases (e.g. citrus greening diseases) that kill produce. Genetic modification can also reduce chemicals in grapefruit that cause side effects in people that take statin drugs.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: The future of the genetic modification of fruits is uncertain, as there's likely to be fear from the public regarding the introduction of them.
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The future of the genetic modification of fruits is uncertain, as there's likely to be fear from the public regarding the introduction of them.

FAQs.question: Does your farm produce any additional crops to maintain revenue during growing seasons?
FAQs.answer: Most citrus farms focus on one type of crop because of climate restrictions.

FAQs.question: Has your farm explored producing organic fruit?
FAQs.answer: Organic trends don't influence most fruit-growing industries.

FAQs.question: How does your business cope with changes in the market price of citrus?
FAQs.answer: Crop and fruit prices largely determine farm revenue since the industry passes on high prices to their buyers.

FAQs.question: How frequently does adverse weather in the region impact your business and how do you manage the related risk?
FAQs.answer: Growers in Florida are significantly affected during hurricane season since hurricanes can destroy orange and citrus crops.

FAQs.question: Does your farm use any genetically modified crops or other biotechnology products?
FAQs.answer: Genetically modified organisms have minimal influence on fruit and vegetable growers. Some farmers have sought to use genetic modification to halt citrus greening, but this has been met with regulatory concerns and a lack of consumer acceptance.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored using automated harvesting or planting equipment?
FAQs.answer: Citrus growers typically have a moderate level of technology. Farmers have been increasingly applying satellite imagery and GPS technology to identify any potential problems with their crops and optimize resource use. Companies have also been employing soil moisture sensors to ensure citrus trees receive the correct amount of water.

FAQs.question: Do you receive any federal subsidies? How much of your revenue do they comprise?
FAQs.answer: Federal subsidies for citrus growers vary based on production volumes. Assistance includes crop insurance programs, direct payments and price supports, research and development funding and emergency aid.

FAQs.question: What organic labeling certifications do you have? How have these regulations impacted your competitiveness?
FAQs.answer: Few citrus growers have focused on obtaining organic certification since organic crops are a niche product.

FAQs.question: How has COVID-19 affected your company's profitability?
FAQs.answer: Profit has been volatile in this industry since profitability is dependent on agricultural prices, the level of international trade and weather conditions.

FAQs.question: How does your farm compensate for the seasonality of cash flow?
FAQs.answer: Some citrus growers also raise livestock to prevent fluctuations in cash flow.

FAQs.question: Are you able to alter the balance between orange crops and other products in response to market conditions?
FAQs.answer: Growers can maximize returns by altering the balance between orange crops and other products in response to changes in market conditions.

FAQs.question: Is your grove located in a fertile area? What kind of growing conditions do you experience? Have you had problems with harvest levels or crop quality?
FAQs.answer: The presence of fertile soils and other appropriate growing conditions is critical in shaping the success of growing citrus fruit. Growing conditions influence harvest levels and crop quality.

FAQs.question: Do you find that demand for fresh fruit and vegetables is affected by attitudes toward nutrition? Why do you think consumption is going to decrease?
FAQs.answer: Fruit and vegetable retailers are important outlets for the fresh fruit produced by this industry. Fruit sold on the fresh market provides substantially higher returns for growers than processed fruit. As demand from retailers increases, so will revenue.

FAQs.question: As the population continues to grow, do you see a change in your revenue? Are you prepared to meet the rising demand for citrus?
FAQs.answer: In addition to rising per capita citrus fruit consumption, the expanding population helps increase the total level of consumption and boosts revenue growth. At the same time, a rapidly expanding population can lead to residential development in land that had previously been devoted to citrus groves, decreasing the acreage devoted to citrus crops. For this reason, population growth can have alternating effects on revenue.
